   \text{Coc-H}^+\text{Cl}^- \ (solid) \xrightarrow{\text{H}_2\text{O}} \text{Coc-H}^+ \ (aq) + \text{Cl}^- \ (aq)
   \]

2. **Base Deprotonation**:  
   Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) dissolves in water and acts as a weak base, releasing hydroxide ions (OH⁻) indirectly via equilibrium:  
   \[
   \text{NaHCO}_3 \rightarrow \text{Na}^+ + \text{HCO}_3^-  
   \]  
   \[
   \text{HCO}_3^- + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{H}_2\text{CO}_3 + \text{OH}^-
   \]  
   The hydroxide (OH⁻) abstracts a proton (H⁺) from the cocaine cation (Coc-H⁺), breaking the ionic bond to Cl⁻:  
   \[
   \text{Coc-H}^+ + \text{OH}^- \rightarrow \text{Coc} \ (freebase) + \text{H}_2\text{O}
   \]  

3. **Formation of Freebase Cocaine**:  
   The freebase cocaine (Coc) is neutral and nonpolar, making it insoluble in water. It precipitates out as a solid, while the chloride (Cl⁻) and sodium (Na⁺) ions remain in solution.
